examples: The minister declared that new measures would be introduced.
The company declared bankruptcy last week.
She declared her intention to run for office.
declare.register: Formal - Use in: essays, reports, news, official statements

state.definition: express something clearly in speech or writing
examples: The report states that unemployment has decreased.
He stated his position clearly during the meeting.
Please state your name and address for the record.
state.register: Formal - Use in: academic writing, reports, formal correspondence

examples: She mentioned that she would be late.
Did I mention my trip to Paris?
The article mentions several important points.
mention.register: Neutral - Use in: everyday conversation, informal writing, casual contexts

remark.definition: say something as a comment; make an observation
examples: He remarked that the weather had improved.
Several people remarked on her new hairstyle.
The teacher remarked that standards were rising.
remark.register: Formal - Use in: literature, formal speech, written commentary

assert.definition: state a fact or belief confidently and forcefully
examples: She asserted that the policy was discriminatory.
The defendant continued to assert his innocence.
He asserted his authority as team leader.
assert.register: Formal - Use in: academic writing, legal contexts, debates

claim.definition: state that something is true, without necessarily providing evidence
examples: He claims that he was at home all evening.
The company claims to be environmentally friendly.
Scientists claim to have made a breakthrough.
claim.register: Neutral - Use in: news reports, academic writing, general discussion

maintain.definition: state something strongly believed to be true
examples: She maintains that the decision was correct.
He maintained his innocence throughout the trial.
The government maintains that reforms are necessary.
maintain.register: Formal - Use in: academic writing, legal contexts, formal arguments

express.definition: convey a thought or feeling in words
examples: She expressed her concern about the situation.
He found it difficult to express his emotions.
The letter expresses gratitude for their support.
express.register: Neutral - Use in: all contexts, very common in both speech and writing

announce.definition: make a public or formal statement about something
examples: The company announced that profits had increased.
She announced her resignation yesterday.
They announced their engagement at the party.
announce.register: Formal - Use in: news, official statements, public declarations

examples: She commented that the film was excellent.
The minister refused to comment on the allegations.
Several experts have commented on the findings.
comment.register: Neutral - Use in: journalism, discussion, giving opinions

yell.definition: shout loudly, usually out of anger, excitement, or pain
examples: The coach yelled instructions from the sidelines.
She yelled at him for being late again.
I heard someone yelling for help.
yell.register: Informal - Use in: everyday speech, emotional reactions

scream.definition: make a loud, high-pitched cry due to fear, pain, or excitement
examples: She screamed when she saw the spider.
He screamed in pain when he fell.
They screamed for help during the fire.
scream.register: Neutral - Use in: emotional descriptions, narratives

bellow.definition: shout something with a deep, loud roar
examples: The sergeant bellowed orders across the field.
He bellowed at the children to come inside.
She bellowed his name across the room.
bellow.register: Neutral/Formal - Use in: dramatic narration, strong emphasis

roar.definition: shout in a loud, deep voice; make a booming sound
examples: The crowd roared when the team scored.
He roared at them to stop immediately.
She roared with laughter at the joke.
roar.register: Neutral - Use in: narratives, describing loud or overwhelming sound

whisper.definition: speak very softly, using breath rather than vocal cords
examples: She whispered her secret to me quietly.
He whispered that he was afraid.
They whispered to each other during the meeting.
whisper.register: Neutral - Use in: intimate or quiet situations

murmur.definition: say something softly and often indistinctly
examples: She murmured her agreement under her breath.
He murmured something I couldn't understand.
The audience murmured in surprise.
murmur.register: Formal/Literary - Use in: descriptive or atmospheric writing

mumble.definition: speak quietly and indistinctly, making it hard to understand
examples: He mumbled an apology.
She mumbled to herself while searching for her keys.
The child mumbled a response.
mumble.register: Neutral - Use in: everyday speech, descriptions of unclear speaking

mutter.definition: speak in a low voice, often complaining or annoyed
examples: He muttered something about unfair treatment.
She muttered under her breath in frustration.
The students muttered complaints during the exam.
mutter.register: Neutral - Use in: describing annoyance, frustration, secrecy

breathe.definition: say something very softly, as if exhaling
examples: She breathed a single word of thanks.
He breathed her name softly.
No one breathed a word about the plan.
breathe.register: Literary - Use in: poetic or dramatic description

think.definition: have a particular opinion or idea
examples: I think this approach will be more effective.
She thought about the problem for hours.
What do you think of the proposal?

know.definition: be aware of something or have information about it
examples: She didn’t know how important it was.
I know that you're telling the truth.
Do you know when the meeting starts?
know.register: Neutral - Use in: all everyday and academic contexts

understand.definition: grasp the meaning, significance, or nature of something
examples: I understand your concerns.
She didn't understand the instructions.
It's important to understand how the system works.
understand.register: Neutral/Formal - Use in: academic and everyday communication

examples: He couldn't comprehend why she was upset.
The concept is difficult to comprehend.
She finally comprehended the complexity of the issue.
comprehend.register: Formal - Use in: academic writing, detailed explanations

realize.definition: become aware of something; understand clearly
examples: She didn’t realize how important it was.
I suddenly realized I had left my phone at home.
Do you realize what this means?

recognize.definition: identify something from previous experience or knowledge
examples: I didn't recognize him at first.
Scientists recognize that the issue is urgent.
She recognized the song immediately.
recognize.register: Neutral - Use in: academic and everyday language

appreciate.definition: recognize the value or importance of something
examples: I really appreciate classical music.
We appreciate your support.
She appreciates that the task is difficult.
appreciate.register: Neutral/Formal - Use in: polite and formal communication

examples: He failed to grasp the main idea.
She grasped the concept quickly.
It took time to grasp what had happened.
grasp.register: Neutral/Formal - Use in: academic and technical contexts

be aware of.definition: know about something; be conscious of something
examples: Are you aware of the risks?
She was aware that he was lying.
We should be aware of cultural differences.
be aware of.register: Neutral - Use in: all practical and formal contexts

acknowledge.definition: admit or accept the truth or existence of something
examples: He acknowledged that mistakes were made.
The company acknowledged the problem.
She acknowledged her responsibility.
acknowledge.register: Formal - Use in: academic, legal, and professional settings

want.definition: desire to have or do something
examples: She wants to travel abroad.
I want a new laptop.
They want us to join them.
She desires a change in her life.
They desire to improve their living conditions.
He desired success above all else.
desire.register: Formal - Use in: academic writing, literature, strong emotional contexts

wish.definition: want something to happen or to be true
examples: I wish to speak with the manager.
She wishes for peace.
I wish that things were different.
wish.register: Neutral - Use in: polite requests, formal situations

seek.definition: try to obtain or achieve something
examples: They seek to improve productivity.
The organization seeks financial support.
She is seeking a new opportunity.
seek.register: Formal - Use in: academic, business, and professional writing

aspire to.definition: have a strong desire to achieve something
examples: Many students aspire to study abroad.
He aspires to become a doctor.
They aspire to leadership roles.
aspire to.register: Formal - Use in: career goals, academic contexts

long for.definition: want something very much; yearn for
examples: She longed for a break from work.
He longed to see his family again.
They longed for freedom.
long for.register: Neutral/Literary - Use for emotional desire, narratives

examples: She craved chocolate.
He craves attention.
They crave adventure and excitement.
crave.register: Informal/Neutral - Use in: emotional or strong desires

yearn for.definition: feel a strong desire or longing for something
examples: She yearned for independence.
He yearned to return home.
They yearned for a simpler life.
yearn for.register: Formal/Literary - Use in: emotional or poetic descriptions

walk.definition: move at a regular pace by lifting and setting down each foot
examples: We walked to the station.
She walks around the park every morning.
He walked home after school.
walk.register: Neutral - Use in: all everyday contexts

stroll.definition: walk in a relaxed, slow way
examples: They strolled along the riverbank.
We strolled around the market.
She went for a quiet stroll.
stroll.register: Neutral - Use in: narratives, relaxed descriptions

wander.definition: walk without a fixed purpose; move aimlessly
examples: We wandered through the old streets.
He wandered off without telling anyone.
Her mind wandered during the lecture.
wander.register: Neutral - Use in: casual and descriptive contexts

march.definition: walk with regular, firm steps, often with purpose or in a group
examples: The soldiers marched in formation.
She marched into the office demanding answers.
Protesters marched through the city center.
march.register: Neutral - Use in: descriptions of purposeful or military movement

examples: He strode confidently into the room.
She strode across the hall to greet him.
The director strode towards us.
stride.register: Neutral - Use in: vivid descriptive writing

pace.definition: walk with repeated steps, usually due to anxiety or deep thought
examples: He paced back and forth while waiting.
She paced around the room in frustration.
The manager paced nervously before the meeting.
pace.register: Neutral - Use in: describing nervous movement

tiptoe.definition: walk quietly and carefully on your toes
examples: She tiptoed into the room so as not to wake the baby.
He tiptoed around the subject to avoid conflict.
They tiptoed past the sleeping dog.
tiptoe.register: Neutral - Use in: quiet or cautious movement

trudge.definition: walk slowly and with heavy steps, often because of exhaustion
examples: They trudged through the snow.
He trudged home after a long day.
She trudged up the hill despite the rain.
trudge.register: Neutral - Use in: describing tired or difficult movement

stomp.definition: walk with heavy, noisy steps, often angrily
examples: She stomped into the room angrily.
He stomped around the house in frustration.
The child stomped up the stairs.
stomp.register: Informal - Use in: emotional or childish movement

shuffle.definition: walk by dragging one's feet along the ground
examples: He shuffled across the room in his slippers.
The old man shuffled slowly forward.
She shuffled nervously in her seat.
shuffle.register: Neutral - Use in: describing hesitant or slow movement

amble.definition: walk in a slow, relaxed way
examples: They ambled along the riverbank.
He ambled through the market.
We ambled home after dinner.
amble.register: Neutral - Use in: relaxed descriptions of movement

saunter.definition: walk slowly and confidently, in a relaxed manner
examples: He sauntered into the room as if he owned the place.
They sauntered along the promenade.
She sauntered past them without a care.
saunter.register: Neutral/Literary - Use in: descriptive, narrative contexts

go.definition: move from one place to another
examples: We went to the museum.
She goes to work by train.
They went home early.

proceed.definition: move forward or continue with an action
examples: You may proceed with the presentation.
The ceremony proceeded as planned.
We can proceed once everyone is ready.
proceed.register: Formal - Use in: meetings, instructions, official contexts

travel.definition: go from one place to another, typically over a distance
examples: She loves to travel around Europe.
We traveled to Italy last summer.
He travels frequently for work.
We headed straight to the train station.
They headed for the exit.
She headed home early.
head.register: Neutral - Use in: everyday conversation, narratives

move.definition: change position or go from one place to another
examples: She moved closer to the window.
They moved to London last year.
He moved away from the door.

advance.definition: move forward, typically in a purposeful way
examples: The troops advanced on the city.
Technology has advanced rapidly.
She advanced towards her goal.
advance.register: Formal - Use in: military, academic, or technical contexts

depart.definition: leave, especially in a formal or organized way
examples: The train departs at noon.
They departed from the airport on time.
The delegation departed early.
depart.register: Formal - Use in: transport, official reports

journey.definition: travel from one place to another, often long distance
examples: They journeyed across the desert.
He journeyed to Rome for the festival.
We journeyed through several countries.
journey.register: Neutral/Formal - Use in: storytelling, travel writing

progress.definition: move forward or develop towards a better state
examples: The project is progressing well.
She progressed rapidly in her studies.
Work progressed slowly due to delays.
progress.register: Formal - Use in: academic, business, project contexts

run.definition: move at a speed faster than walking
examples: She ran to catch the bus.
He runs every morning.
They ran away from the dog.

sprint.definition: run at full speed over a short distance
examples: He sprinted towards the finish line.
She sprinted across the field.
They sprinted to safety.
sprint.register: Neutral - Use in: sports, urgent movement

dash.definition: run or move quickly and suddenly
examples: She dashed to the station to catch her train.
He dashed across the street.
I must dash off now.
dash.register: Neutral - Use in: dynamic, fast-paced descriptions

examples: He raced to finish the report.
The children raced each other across the field.
We raced against time to complete the project.
He rushed to get ready.
She rushed through her homework.
They rushed into the room looking worried.
Hurry up! We're late.
She hurried to finish before the deadline.
They hurried across the street.
The horse bolted from the gate.
He bolted when he heard the shout.
The rabbit bolted into the bushes.
bolt.register: Neutral - Use in: animal movement, sudden running

charge.definition: move quickly and aggressively towards something
examples: The bull charged at the fence.
He charged into the room full of energy.
They charged forward with determination.
charge.register: Neutral - Use in: battles, sports, aggressive movement

tear.definition: move quickly in a reckless or hurried way
examples: He tore across the field to catch the ball.
She tore out of the driveway.
They tore along the road in excitement.
tear.register: Informal - Use in: lively or chaotic movement

examples: The car sped past us.
He sped home after the meeting.
They sped through the tunnel.
The motorcycle zoomed past us.
She zoomed through her homework.
The children zoomed around the playground.
zoom.register: Informal - Use in: quick movement, playful contexts

examples: She looked at the sky.
I'm looking for my keys.
We will look into the matter.

gaze.definition: look steadily and intently, especially with admiration
examples: She gazed at the stars.
He gazed into her eyes.
They gazed upon the landscape.
gaze.register: Neutral/Formal - Use in: narrative, emotional scenes

glance.definition: quickly look at something or someone
examples: She glanced at her watch.
He glanced over the document.
At a glance, everything seemed fine.
glance.register: Neutral - Use in: all descriptive contexts

peer.definition: look closely or carefully at something, often with difficulty
examples: She peered into the darkness.
He peered at the small print.
They peered through the window.
peer.register: Neutral - Use in: detailed or investigative looking

observe.definition: watch something carefully, especially to gain information
examples: Scientists observed the changes closely.
I observed that she was nervous.
We must observe the rules.
observe.register: Formal - Use in: scientific, academic contexts

examine.definition: look at something closely and carefully
examples: The doctor examined the patient.
Police examined the crime scene.
We examined the evidence thoroughly.
examine.register: Formal - Use in: investigative, professional contexts

glimpse.definition: see something or someone briefly or partially
examples: I caught a glimpse of her as she left.
We glimpsed the castle through the trees.
He glimpsed a shadow moving.
glimpse.register: Neutral - Use in: fleeting visual descriptions

examples: She glared at him in anger.
He glared across the room.
The teacher glared at the noisy students.
glare.register: Neutral - Use in: conflict or emotional tension

scan.definition: look at all parts of something carefully, often searching for something
examples: She scanned the list for her name.
He scanned the crowd for familiar faces.
We scanned the document quickly.
scan.register: Neutral - Use in: searching or inspection

eye.definition: look at someone or something carefully or suspiciously
examples: She eyed him suspiciously.
He eyed the cake hungrily.
They eyed each other cautiously.

see.definition: perceive with the eyes; notice or become aware of
examples: I saw him at the station.
Did you see that bird?
I see what you mean.

notice.definition: become aware of something, especially something small
examples: I noticed a mistake in the report.
She didn't notice that he was upset.
Did you notice anything unusual?
notice.register: Neutral - Use in: everyday and academic contexts

spot.definition: see or notice someone or something, often difficult to detect
examples: She spotted her friend in the crowd.
He spotted several errors.
They spotted a rare bird.
spot.register: Neutral - Use in: noticing small details

perceive.definition: become aware of or interpret something through the senses
examples: He perceived a change in her behavior.
The public perceives the issue differently.
She perceived that something was wrong.
perceive.register: Formal - Use in: academic or scientific contexts

detect.definition: discover or identify the presence of something
examples: The test detects early signs of disease.
Police detected unusual activity.
Scientists detected a new particle.
detect.register: Formal - Use in: technical, scientific, investigative contexts

witness.definition: see an event take place, especially a significant one
examples: They witnessed the accident.
He witnessed history in the making.
Several people witnessed the incident.
witness.register: Formal - Use in: legal, historical, or narrative contexts

examples: We viewed the exhibition.
The proposal is viewed as beneficial.
She viewed the data carefully.
view.register: Formal - Use in: reports, analysis, academic writing

discern.definition: recognize or identify something with effort
examples: I could barely discern his voice.
She discerned a pattern in the data.
They discerned that something was wrong.
discern.register: Formal - Use in: academic, analytic, or detailed writing

watch.definition: look at or observe attentively over a period of time
examples: We watched a movie.
She watched the children playing.
He watches the news every evening.

monitor.definition: observe and check the progress or quality of something
examples: Scientists monitor climate patterns.
We monitored the patient's condition.
The system monitors performance automatically.
monitor.register: Formal - Use in: scientific and technical contexts

regard.definition: pay careful attention to something; consider
examples: The theory is widely regarded as groundbreaking.
She regarded him with suspicion.
He is regarded as a leader.
regard.register: Formal - Use in: academic and professional contexts

scrutinize.definition: examine something very carefully and critically
examples: The documents were scrutinized thoroughly.
Experts scrutinized the data for errors.
She scrutinized his expression.
scrutinize.register: Formal - Use in: academic, legal, analytical contexts

survey.definition: examine and record something from a broad perspective
examples: They surveyed public opinion.
The land was surveyed for construction.
She surveyed the room before speaking.
survey.register: Formal - Use in: research, analysis, assessments

keep an eye on.definition: watch something or someone carefully to ensure safety or proper behavior
examples: Can you keep an eye on my bag?
She kept an eye on the children while they played.
He asked me to keep an eye on the oven.
keep an eye on.register: Informal - Use in: everyday supervision or casual instructions

examples: I got a new phone yesterday.
She got angry when she saw the mess.
They got permission to enter.
She obtained her degree from Cambridge University.
You must obtain permission before entering.
This information is difficult to obtain.
obtain.register: Formal - Use in: official documents, academic writing, formal requests

acquire.definition: buy or obtain an asset or come to have a skill
examples: The company acquired several new businesses.
Students acquire language skills through practice.
She has acquired extensive experience.
acquire.register: Formal - Use in: business, education, technical contexts

receive.definition: be given or presented with something
examples: I received your message yesterday.
She received a scholarship.
The idea was well received.
receive.register: Neutral/Formal - Use in: polite and formal contexts

examples: She gained confidence after the event.
They gained experience during the internship.
What do you hope to gain?
gain.register: Neutral - Use in: progress, learning, improvement

achieve.definition: successfully bring about or reach a desired objective
examples: She achieved her dream of becoming a doctor.
The company achieved record profits.
We aim to achieve better outcomes.
achieve.register: Formal - Use in: academic, business, motivational contexts

attain.definition: succeed in achieving something, especially after effort
examples: He attained a high level of skill.
Few athletes attain this level of excellence.
The goals were eventually attained.
attain.register: Formal - Use in: academic or high-level achievements

secure.definition: obtain something, especially after effort; make safe
examples: They secured funding for the project.

procure.definition: obtain something, especially with effort or difficulty
examples: They managed to procure the necessary documents.

procure.register: Formal - Use in: government, logistics, legal contexts

earn.definition: receive money or gain something as a result of effort
examples: She earns $50,000 a year.
He earned the respect of his colleagues.
They earned a place in the finals.
earn.register: Neutral - Use in: everyday, business, academic contexts

examples: She made a cake.
He made me laugh.
They made several improvements.
The program created new jobs.
She created a beautiful painting.
We need to create better systems.
create.register: Neutral/Formal - Use in: professional, creative, academic contexts

examples: The company produces electronic devices.
The experiment produced unexpected results.
This factory produces thousands of units per day.
produce.register: Neutral/Formal - Use in: business, manufacturing, scientific contexts

generate.definition: produce or create something, especially energy or ideas
examples: The report generated a lot of discussion.
Solar panels generate electricity.
Her speech generated enthusiasm.
generate.register: Formal - Use in: business, science, academic contexts

construct.definition: build or form something by putting parts together
examples: They constructed a new bridge.
Students constructed a model of the system.
The building was constructed last year.
construct.register: Formal - Use in: engineering, academic, technical contexts

build.definition: construct something by putting parts or materials together
examples: They built a new school.

build.register: Neutral - Use in: general and professional contexts

examples: The team formed a strategy.
Ice forms on the lake in winter.
They formed a partnership.
form.register: Formal - Use in: academic and professional contexts

establish.definition: set up, create, or found something
examples: The company was established in 1998.
They established clear rules.

establish.register: Formal - Use in: institutional, academic, corporate contexts

develop.definition: grow or cause something to grow and become more advanced
examples: She developed strong leadership skills.
The company is developing new software.
The idea developed into a full project.
develop.register: Neutral/Formal - Use in: professional, academic contexts

craft.definition: make something with skill and careful attention to detail
examples: She crafted a beautiful sculpture.

craft.register: Neutral/Formal - Use in: creative, professional contexts

manufacture.definition: make something on a large scale using machinery
examples: The factory manufactures cars.
